content: The Act is known as the "Protect Our Workers from Exploitation and Retaliation Act" or the "POWER Act." It aims to protect victims of serious labor and employment violations or crime. The "POWER Act" provides protection for victims of labor and employment violations, amending the Immigration and Nationality Act to include provisions for victims of criminal activity and violations. The "POWER Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to protect victims of labor and employment violations, ensuring they do not suffer extreme hardship upon removal. The "POWER Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to protect victims of labor and employment violations by investigating, prosecuting, or seeking civil remedies for workplace claims related to violations. The "POWER Act" amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to protect victims of labor and employment violations by investigating, prosecuting, or seeking civil remedies for workplace claims related to violations. It includes provisions for aliens involved in workplace claims to be protected if they are witnesses or victims of threats, force, retaliation, or abuse of legal processes. The Secretary of Homeland Security may allow an alien to stay in the US and work if they have filed for relief under section 101(a)(15)(U) of the Immigration and Nationality Act or are involved in a workplace claim as a witness. The text discusses the eligibility criteria for an alien to stay and work in the US under section 101(a)(15)(U) of the Immigration and Nationality Act, including being helpful to various law enforcement and government agencies investigating workplace claims. Amendments are made to section 214(p) of the Act to include investigating authorities. Amendments are made to various paragraphs in the Immigration and Nationality Act to include investigating, prosecuting, or seeking civil remedies for workplace claims described in section 101(a)(15)(U)(iv). Additionally, adjustments are made to section 245(m)(1) regarding the adjustment of status for victims of crimes, including workplace claims. Amendments are made to the Immigration and Nationality Act to include workplace claims in the prosecution process. Changes are made to allow victims of workplace claims to adjust their nonimmigrant classification. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act include workplace claims in the prosecution process and allow victims to adjust their nonimmigrant classification. Labor enforcement actions are addressed in Section 3. Amendments to the Immigration and Nationality Act now include workplace claims in removal proceedings and address labor enforcement actions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include workplace claims in enforcement actions by the Department of Homeland Security. This ensures that aliens arrested or detained are necessary for investigating workplace claim violations or criminal activity. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include workplace claims in enforcement actions by the Department of Homeland Security. Protections are provided for victims of crime, labor, and employment violations, ensuring that aliens involved in criminal activity are not removed until law enforcement is notified and given the opportunity to interview them. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include workplace claims in enforcement actions by the Department of Homeland Security. Aliens facing removal proceedings can receive a stay of removal or abeyance if they have filed a workplace claim, are a witness in a workplace claim proceeding, or have applied for relief under section 101(a)(15)(U), along with employment authorization until the resolution of the claim. The Department can establish, by evidence before the immigration judge, that a stay of removal or abeyance can be revoked if the alien has been convicted of a felony or if the workplace claim was filed in bad faith to delay or avoid removal. The authorization issued under clause (i) remains valid until the resolution of the workplace claim or denial of relief under section 101(a)(15)(U). The Secretary of Homeland Security can extend it for up to 3 additional years if it enables the alien to pursue the claim, serves the deterrent goals of the statute, or if relief is warranted. In this paragraph, the term 'material witness' is defined as an individual who presents a declaration from an attorney investigating, prosecuting, or defending the workplace claim, attesting to the best of the declarant's knowledge. To the best of the declarant's knowledge and belief, reasonable cause exists to believe that the testimony of the individual will be relevant to the outcome of the workplace claim, which includes any written or oral claim related to the violation of labor laws. Labor laws cover various aspects such as wages, hours, labor relations, family and medical leave, occupational health and safety, civil rights, and nondiscrimination. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act and its amendments.
